title: Macron tries to charm Musk, while accusing him of being 'reactionary'
summary: The French president hopes that his relative closeness to the billionaire will put him in a better position of influence than other European leaders.

title: Saudi Arabia, the centerpiece of a Middle East in transition
summary: The kingdom has seen its vision of making economic development the foundation of regional stability overturned by the October 7, 2023, attacks by Hamas in Israel, and their aftermath.

title: Mayotte braces for new cyclone weeks after being hit by Cyclone Chido
summary: France's national weather service has warned heavy rain from incoming Cyclone Dikeledi could cause flooding.

title: Special counsel who led Trump prosecutions leaves US Justice Dept
summary: Jack Smith had accused Trump of conspiracy to defraud the United States and conspiracy to obstruct an official proceeding, but dropped the cases against Trump after he won November's presidential election.

title: LA fires threaten more homes as winds forecast to pick up
summary: Los Angeles residents have increasingly demanded to know who is at fault for the disaster, with local anger rising over officials' preparedness and response. The Palisades fire was 11% contained Saturday and spreading east after burning 22,600 acres. The Eaton Fire in the Altadena area of the city was at 14,000 acres and 15% contained.

title: Jeff Bezos prepares new rocket launch to rival SpaceX
summary: The first flight of the New Glenn rocket will relaunch the space competition between Jeff Bezos and Elon Musk. For now, Musk dominates the sector and wants to widen the gap with his Starship rocket.

title: Lifting sanctions against Syria is key to stabilizing the country
summary: On Monday, Janury 6, Washington granted a six-month exemption from sanctions on transactions with Syrian government institutions. A welcome decision for the new government in Damascus as the country is reeling from years of war.

title: Sudan paramilitary leader says 'lost' Al-Jazira state capital
summary: A video Sudan's army shared on social media showed fighters on the western side of Hantoub Bridge in the city's north after an army source told AFP they had 'stormed the city's eastern entrance.'

title: After decades in exile, the former Greek royal family regains its nationality and creates controversy
summary: In a country where the return to democracy in 1974 resulted in a referendum against the re-establishment of the monarchy, this decision, and the family name chosen by the descendants, have provoked strong criticism.

title: Jean-Marie Le Pen's confession on torture during the Algerian War: 'I do it under the orders of my captain'
summary: The co-founder of France's main far-right party, who died on January 7, never denied his racist, homophobic and anti-Semitic beliefs. He also admitted to carrying out torture in his role as a soldier in the Battle of Algiers.

title: 10 years ago, millions of people took to the streets in France in support of victims of 'Charlie Hebdo' attack
summary: Huge rallies took place across France in support of the victims of recent terrorist attacks. Here's a look back at these historic marches, in pictures.

title: Why South Koreans are chanting Trump's 'Stop the Steal' in support of impeached president Yoon
summary: Supporters of Yoon Suk Yeol are taking inspiration from Donald Trump's MAGA movement. Yoon's lawyers are even drawing arguments from the US president-elect's court cases.

title: Paris-Algiers tensions heighten over failed expulsion of Algerian influencer
summary: France's interior minister accused Algeria of seeking to 'humiliate France,' saying the country will have 'no option but to retaliate' should 'the Algerians continue this posture of escalation.'

title: Who is Joseph Aoun, Lebanon's new president?
summary: The former army chief, a favorite of Washington, Paris and Riyadh, says he wants to rebuild his country, currently in tatters.

title: Syria's HTS 'is a movement that has de-radicalized from the top'
summary: A leading expert on Syria, researcher Patrick Haenni analyzes the nature of the new power stemming from the Hayat Tahrir al-Sham group, and the strategic and security challenges facing the new authorities in Damascus.

title: Paris's last tourist office will close
summary: The office will stop welcoming visitors on Sunday, January 12, a closure that raises the question of the usefulness of these spaces.

title: Meta's partners shocked as Zuckerberg announces end of fact-checking program
summary: On Tuesday, the boss of Meta announced his intention to end the fact-checking partnerships linking his company to certain US media.

title: US weather service estimates total Los Angeles fire damage between $135-150 billion so far
summary: The scale of damage to the second-biggest US city could be the costliest ever recorded, according to AccuWeather. The five separate fires have so far burned more than 35,000 acres, California's fire agency reported.

title: Russia cuts Transnistria's gas supply to destabilize Moldova
summary: A humanitarian catastrophe is looming for the 367,000 inhabitants of Transnistria, a region of Moldova living under pro-Russian separatist control. Counting on rising discontent in both Transnistria and Moldova ahead of the parliamentary elections, the Kremlin intends to topple the pro-European government.

title: Understaffed and overworked: Behind the scenes at France's major museums
summary: The cultural institutions are increasingly calling on subcontractors for security services, audio guide rental, reception and outreach – creating tension within their teams.

title: Mark Zuckerberg wants more 'masculine energy' and less diversity policy
summary: After limiting content moderation, the founder of Meta explained in a podcast interview with Joe Rogan, an avowed supporter of Donald Trump, why he was ending his internal inclusion policies.

title: Seoul confirms Ukraine captured two North Korean soldiers
summary: Ukrainian intelligence (SBU) released a video in June showing the two men in hospital bunks, one with bandaged hands and the other with a bandaged jaw.

title: Potatoes, cheese and lardons: The mysterious story behind la tartiflette, France's favorite comfort food
summary: Far from being an ancestral recipe, this gratin made with reblochon cheese, potatoes, bacon and onions is a child of the 1980s. But few have been able to precisely pin down who created this winter dish.

title: Five winter walks by the sea in France
summary: 'Le Monde' is taking you on a trip. Let's go to the island of Ouessant, Argelès, Lacanau, Saint-Malo and Mont-Saint-Michel, popular destinations for summer visitors, but just as attractive in winter. And you will (almost) be the only ones to enjoy it.

title: In 2024, a series of climate disasters
summary: The most ambitious objective of the Paris Agreement is in great danger: 2024 will be the first year above the threshold of 1.5°C warming compared to the pre-industrial era.

title: Joe Biden honors Ralph Lauren. Does anyone care?
summary: On January 4, the US president awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom to 19 personalities, including the 85-year-old couturier.

title: Tram crash in France leaves 68 injured
summary: Two trams collided in a tunnel in the eastern city of Strasbourg on Saturday.

title: Far-right leader Jordan Bardella's childhood in poor Paris suburb: Separating myth from reality
summary: The far-right Rassemblement National party's president spent part of his youth in Saint-Denis. Among those who knew him at the time – friends and classmates from the private high school where he volunteered to teach French to migrants – his political activism remain surprising.

title: Malala Yousafzai tells Muslim leaders not to 'legitimize' Taliban
summary: The Nobel Peace Prize laureate who was shot by the Taliban in 2012 gave a talk at a two-day conference in front of ministers and education officials from Muslim-majority countries backed by the Muslim World League.

title: Warning bells over cost of French debt
summary: To offset its public deficit, France must take on debt at interest rates not seen since October 2023. Experts warn this could just be the beginning.

title: Storm moves away from Mayotte after causing deadly floods in Madagascar
summary: Mayotte was placed on red alert on Saturday over fears of Storm Dikeledi's approach just weeks after the French territory was devastated by Cyclone Chido.

title: Pompidou Center showcases works collected by perennial rebel Jean-Jacques Lebel
summary: The French modern art museum presents a selection of creations by friends of the writer and anarchist activist, and also by artists he loved, from the endowment fund he launched in 2013.

title: 'The "Charlie Hebdo" murders were radical censorship, with far-reaching consequences for culture'
summary: Le Monde's Michel Guerrin writes that the trauma of January 7, 2015, has created a climate of fear in France's cultural field that is leading to an erosion of freedom of expression, particularly when it comes to religious references.

title: Saudi Arabia urges Syria sanctions relief at talks with regional, EU diplomats
summary: Speaking to the press on Syria, Saudi Arabia's foreign minister said international sanctions should be lifted after rebel groups overthrew regime leader Assad in December, to not 'hinder' the country's development.

title: Trump bashes California leaders over fire response
summary: The US president-elect called Californian politicians 'incompetent' in response to the wildfires that have ravaged Los Angeles. Governor Gavin Newsom told NBC he had invited Trump to come to LA.

title: Macron and the persistent question of a referendum
summary: In his New Year's address, the French president once again raised the possibility of a referendum; something which has been mentioned many times since 2017, but this 'return to the people' has never materialized.

title: Spain approached 50th anniversary of Franco's death divided
summary: Socialist Pedro Sanchez's government opened the commemorations of the dictator's death on Wednesday, in the absence of the far-right and right-wing opposition.

title: Iran confirms return of national held in Italy
summary: Mohammad Abedini Najafabadi was held in Milan after accusations he had supplied drone technology to Iran's military.

title: Sarkozy's trial: The full timeline of the Libyan campaign financing case
summary: Since January 6, the former French president has been on trial over accusations he received funding from Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi for his 2007 presidential campaign. Here is the timeline of what we know, spanning over more than 20 years.
